Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Identity Development on Women's Recidivism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Proposal Title: The Effects of Identity Development on Women's Recidivism Institution: Michigan State University Abstract Date: 06/27/14 This study examines how women offenders' identity development contributes to whether they desist from crime or reoffend, and what factors promote or impair desired identity development among women. Prior tests of narrative identity theory have shown that identity development explains behavior; its application to a study of women offenders on probation and parole for serious felony offenses offers considerable promise for understanding desistance in this population. This research builds upon baseline data from an earlier study of 400 drug-involved women offenders. The new data will generate information on how and why women do or do not change in ways that support breaking off from a pattern of illegal behavior, with particular attention to key features of identity,the types of neighborhoods in which the women live, and factors that impede them from obtaining needed services and assistance. The project examines how known predictors of recidivism work in combination with identity to provide a more complete explanation of outcomes. Findings about identity development will inform correctional, substance abuse treatment, and mental health treatment practitioners' efforts to promote desistance from crime.In-depth life history interviews will be completed with 60 women who recidivated and 60 who did not, supplemented by telephone interviews spaced two years apart with the full sample of 400 women. Interviews will include a number of validated and reliable scales to assess engagement in volunteer work, skill development, and treatment services as well as life satisfaction, motivations to assume prosocial roles, self-reports of contact with the justice system, services needed and received, residential mobility, and proximity to service location. Regression models will be analyzed to predict recidivism from personality indicators in addition to a set of established predictors in the literature,and an established qualitative coding scheme will be adapted to include newly identified themes reflective of women's process of desistance from crime. In combination, this will provide a strong test of the nature and effect of identity development for drug-involved women offenders. Findings will inform evidence-based correctional practices that promote desistance and will suggest interventions useful for women offenders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aims of the project, “The Effects of Identity Development on Women's Recidivism,” were to develop a very complete explanation for why some women, but not others, continued illegal activity during or after being supervised on probation or parole.  For 118 women at high risk of reoffending, a specific interest was whether women’s identity developed in ways that supported their stopping criminal activity. For a group of over 300 women, the study also identified the major risks for recidivism and it showed whether changes in these risks predicted recidivism.  The specific risks were:  antisocial friends, family support and conflict, adult abuse, crime-ridden neighborhood, unsafe housing, depression/anxiety, substance abuse, anger/hostility, low self-efficacy, post-traumatic stress disorder, employment and financial need, number of unmet needs for social benefits, high educational needs, and low educational strengths.  The findings will help professionals who supervise or provide treatment for women offenders by showing the connection between how women see themselves and their lives and desistance from crime, and by showing the risk factors for recidivism. 

This summary will first present findings about identity development and how it is related to desistance from crime.  This information was obtained from detailed life stories that the 118 women with the highest level of risk of recidivism shared with interviewers.  As Table 1 shows, relatively high proportions (70% or higher) of women with one of the following experiences desisted from illegal activity:  (1) they drew on treatment and other experiences to recover from substance dependencies or addiction,  (2)  they used their experiences of being neglected or abused as children to improve their own approach to parenting, or (3) they used negative experiences connected to their own criminal behavior and drug use to help other people avoid or recover from these problems.  Very few women (only 10) described the experience of gaining an education by finishing high school, earning a GED, or attending college, but a high proportion of those who did have an educational achievement desisted from crime. Surprisingly, gaining employment after a period of unemployment was not related to desistance.  The explanation for this unexpected finding is that nearly all of these women obtained employment in low paying jobs that often did not guarantee full time work or continuation of employment.  The women’s life stories show the importance of substance abuse treatment, learning from past negative experiences, and opportunities to help other people avoid crime and drug use for promoting desistance.  They also show the need for improved employment opportunities for the high-risk offenders who were interviewed. 

Phone interviews were conducted with the high risk women who told their life stories as well as women who were at medium and low risk for recidivism.  The phone interviews provided measures of several psychological (e.g., anxiety/depression, anger/hostility) and economic (e.g., employment problems and financial need) variables.  Official police information provided measures of criminal history (the number of prior arrests), and of recidivism as indicated by the number of new arrests.  Criminal history was a very strong predictor of recidivism, and once criminal history, age, and race/ethnicity were taken into account, none of the psychological and economic variables increased the ability to predict recidivism.  Also, changes in the psychological and economic variables did not increase the ability to predict recidivism beyond what could be predicted by criminal history, age, and race/ethnicity. 

These findings show that helping women change their identities, for example in substance abuse treatment or through learning from past negative events, may be quite important in designing and delivering programming that promotes high-risk offenders’ desistence from crime.  Also, at least for the sample studied, there is a need to increase opportunities for education and stable employment.  For women who were not in the high-risk group, changes in a wide variety of risk factors did not improve explanation of their recidivism beyond what was predicted from the seriousness of their criminal involvement before the research began.

The research was unique because it used more than one theory of why people stop breaking the law, and it collected both qualitative and quantitative data.  It also focused on a group of offenders that has not been extensively studied before.  The specific group was women felons who include many who are at high risk for offending.  Because of the unique features of the research, the project provided the opportunity to train several graduate students to carry out quantitative and qualitative research that draws on multiple theories and that is designed to be relevant to women offenders.
